1341.96.text: I was brought up in Manchester.

1357.89.text:

1361.70.text:
And I think that

1364.37.text:

part of who we are

1371.99.text: as human beings in our fullest.

1374.57.text:
And if we watch nature
programs on television,

1378.26.text:
we see that migration
is part of the pattern

1382.37.text: and the DNA of the world.

1386.06.text:
To be anti-migration
is to be anti-nature.

1390.26.text:
So this sense of
belonging in the poem

1394.34.text:
is tied to the sense of what
it feels like to be British.

1400.65.text:
Our nation now, but it
was the same in the 60s,

1407.57.text:
But how we react to
that change tells me

1417.70.text:
Hold me, while the spirits of
the past and rivers of blood

1423.49.text:
All this past feeds this present
and brings the truth into me.

1427.54.text:
His story, your search,
his journey, ours.

1430.78.text:
Something rings true
inside and strong.

1434.86.text:
I stand atop Piccadilly Tower
and sing, I belong here.

1442.42.text:
I the Mogadishan who
knows troubled waters.

1446.77.text:
I the Belfast man who
knows troubled cities.

1451.59.text:
I the Ethiopian who
knows troubled lands.

1456.56.text:
I the Serbian who crosses
troubled seas, who

1460.72.text:
walked through darkened valleys
under the shadows of death

1464.41.text:
and bled, and who lay
amongst the freshly killed

1472.99.text:
Those who have cried
cities, sobbed roads.

1477.22.text:
In the name of
here and where they

1479.89.text:
came from stand atop the
bridge water hall, and sing,

1505.82.text:
it means house-- and
sing, I belong here.

1515.83.text:
Poets are like the temperature
gauge of a people, I believe.

1519.76.text:
And that's why those
poems, you know,

1521.89.text: were written at the Arab Spring.

1524.75.text:
And that's why poems
become national anthems.

1527.29.text:
And that's why poems
become Christmas carols.

1530.19.text:
And that's why poems
are read at funerals,

1532.00.text:
because they're a bridge between
the physical and the spiritual.

1535.69.text:
Every range of
emotion you'll get

1537.28.text:
in one evening of spoken word,
from politics to heartbreak.

1541.99.text:
That communal aspect of spoken
word or performance poetry,

1545.33.text:
whatever you want to call
it, I think it's lovely.

1547.42.text:
It's kind of how it all
began, is storytelling.

1549.56.text:
Poetry has always
been a kind of gateway

1554.98.text:
Yeah, it's the
good stuff, poetry.

1557.80.text:
I don't know why it isn't
on television every night.
